oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1873 History of Memphis
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: City of Memphis; history; books;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A digital copy of James D. Davis' 1873 book, "The History of the City of Memphis: being a compilation of the most important documents and historical events connected with the purchase of its territory, laying off of the city and early settlement. Also, The 'Old Times Papers,' being a series of reminiscences and local stories written by the author, and published in the Daily Appeal over the signature of 'Old Times,' corrected, revised and enlarged, with other important matters pertaining to the same, never heretofore published, and, beyond the author, but partially known." This particular copy is from the Library of Congress, but copies in the Memphis Public Library can be found at the call number 976.819 D262H.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Video - Memphis in Early 1970s
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: buildings; businesses; children; hospitals; industry; music; recreation; schools; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A brief introduction to Memphis from about 1972. The footage from the Danny Thomas Memphis Classic and the Memphis Music Awards is from 1971.

1970s Film Log
“Old Man River lapping, ever lapping, and then rolling away gently to the sea. Long before 1541, when DeSoto stood upon our bluff and discovered the Mississippi River, the indians plowed the stream in their canoes and coaxed the fish from their water of temples and killed wild game on its banks. Memphis knows nothing of the river’s infancy, of that far-away time when it started to flow down to the sea. Long before the coming of the railroads, the Mississippi River was the main artery of travel. The ways of the old south swept down the river. Passengers by the thousands landed at the foot of Beale Street. There was music then and dancing down there by night. There is to be found most of the romance and adventure that made the river famous.”
Downtown buildings residences churches bridges riverfront airplanes Memphis International Airport Danny Thomas Danny Thomas Memphis Classic [1971] golf Lee Trevino St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital
[3:20] “Memphis has one of the largest hospital complexes in the country. It’s a very important part of the city. All of the facilities and equipment are impressive, but the important thing is what we are actually doing. It’s being able to let a child live, to relieve someone’s pain, or to learn something that will give someone a new and a better life. That’s the important thing. People, that’s why we are here. We are thousands, working together in an atmosphere of healing, learning and hope. It’s really a beautiful thing.”
medicine hospitals children Baptist Memorial Hospital Memphis Zoo animals Pink Palace circus Mid-South Fair amusement parks Liberty Bowl football polo horses ballet symphony Metropolitan Opera
[6:50] “Why they’ve never written some sonnet or song about the Cotton Carnival will never be known. For this is mother nature’s brightest stage - Memphis in May. Sometimes the moments we count or the times we remember best are not the highlights of the season. It might be a quiet crowd of two. Or a small, familiar clan exploring a gourmet’s work by candlelight.”
Cotton Carnival romance Lara Parker food restaurants shopping retail fashion antique cars streets Holiday Inn nightlife T.G.I. Friday’s jazz Marvin Stamm
[9:12] “The sleepless giants of Memphis are our industries. The tools of our progress are hard work, initiative and inventiveness.”
manufacturing Firestone computers IBM Schering-Plough military Riverside Drive construction Hernando-DeSoto Bridge
[10:36] “Schools are important for everybody - for the community and the whole society - but most of all for the individual. The schools are basically just buildings, but with the people they come alive. It’s a new generation every year, a step toward a new awareness and a bringing of people together. It’s a good thing all around.”
University of Tennessee Memphis State University Lemoyne-Owen College Christian Brothers College Southwestern at Memphis education
[11:00] “Today a bright new recording center, Memphis presents fine music to the world. It’s a long way from W. C. Handy to Elvis Presley, but the Memphis sound is big enough for all. The Memphis Music Awards annually honor outstanding musicians who have contributed to the music of Memphis.” [George W. Lee speech excerpt from awards - May, 1971: “I accept this in the name of a gorgeous and melodramatic figure, who looked across to the Arkansas side of the Mississippi River and saw the gorgeous evening sunset in russet [unintelligible], and a song rose in his heart.”] “In the program are celebrated artists, such as B.J. Thomas, Dionne Warwick, and Isaac Hayes. Styles vary widely, from the genesis of the blues to the rock-and-roll and rhythm and blues of today. You can’t help but want to move with it. Ask Rufus Thomas.”
Steve Cropper music recording studio Memphis Music Awards George W. Lee blues W. C. Handy B. J. Thomas Dionne Warwick Isaac Hayes Rufus Thomas albums
Credits:
presented by The Memphis Area Chamber of Commerce
“I’d rather be here than any place I know…” W.C. Handy
directed by Jimmy Huston photography by Paul Barton produced by Peter J. Barton Productions, Inc.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Video - 1949 Clean-Up, Fix-Up Campaign
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: beautification; City Beautiful Commission; entertainment; events; pageants; parades; 1940s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A film from the 1949 Memphis Clean-Up, Paint-Up, Fix-Up Campaign. Highlights include the Miss City Beautiful beauty pageant, a train tour of Memphis, and a "follies" show at a community center.

1949 Film Log (taken from title cards within film)
00:01 - “Memphis, Tennessee the ‘Nation’s Cleanest City’ - Reception at Hotel Peabody in tribute for winning ‘Nation’s Cleanest City’ trophy.” 1940s City Beautiful Commission parties events fashion
04:42 - “Plans for 1949 campaign are discussed by Mayor and President of the Memphis Chamber of Commerce.” Overton, Watkins Robertson, Caffey
05:29 - “Chairman and Co-chairman outline program for 1949 campaign.” Fowler, Margaret Burks, O. O. Fredericks, Robert S.
06:04 - “City Beautiful Commission staff prepares for campaign.” women offices
07:25 - “Campaign is officially opened with Kick-Off luncheon.” events dining Overton, Watkins Fowler, Margaret Robertson, Caffey Burks, O. O.
08:57 - “Gala parade down Main Street attracts huge crowd.” (Main and Court) parades Main Street The Style Shop National Shirt Shops Walgreen Drugs Darling Shop marching bands majorettes Oak Hall Memphis Fire Department Memphis Park Commission
11:08 - “Hundreds of playground children take part in colorful costumes.” children Peabody Community Center tractors Boy Scouts Bellevue Jr. High crossing guards Court Square Longview Heights Civic Club
14:30 - “‘Miss City Beautiful’ and contestants ride attractive float and cars.” [sic] Sanders, Betty automobiles Health Department Memphis Department of Public Works Salvation Army
19:10 - “Prizes are awarded parade winners.” [sic]
20:29 - “Forty-eight attractive girls enter ‘Miss City Beautiful’ contest.” women beauty pageants
20:54 - “Contestants parade before the judges.”
23:21 - “Bouquets are presented to the three finalists.”
23:53 - “The winner - Miss Betty Sanders - ‘Miss City Beautiful’ of 1949”
25:44 - “Five bus loads of prominent citizens depart on Rehabilitation Bus Tour.” Peabody Hotel buses
26:46 - “Inspection is made of new four-lane highway bridge under construction.” Memphis-Arkansas Bridge Mississippi River
28:19 - “Guests visit one of Memphis’ outstanding flower gardens.” residences
29:29 - “Group views special painting project.” Madison Avenue Graham Apartments
30:36 - “Refreshments are enjoyed at City Beautiful Commission Headquarters.” (1430 Eastmoreland)
32:20 - “Plants and shrubs are exchanged at Garden Mart.”
35:50 - “Civic leaders take train tour to inspect railroad property and industrial areas.” Memphis-Arkansas Bridge industry railroads J.E. Dilworth Co. Front St. Warehouse Riverside Drive International Harvester Illinois Central Railroad public housing Desoto Paint and Varnish Co.
44:42 - “Clean-Up Campaign activities are explained at dinner for school principals.” dining
46:13 - “Committee inspects schools for fire hazards.” schools Bellevue Jr. High Memphis Fire Department
47:13 - “Unscheduled fire drills are held in all schools.” schools American Legion
48:39 - “Winners in Garden Club contest.” women awards
49:02 - “Winners in Health Department Inspection contest.” Phelan’s House Paint awards
49:54 - “Dr. Cu-Pu-Fu Follies performs in neighborhood community centers. Prizes were awarded and talks made on spring clean-up.” events entertainment community centers dance
58:39 - “Hundreds enjoyed Spuare Dance in downtown Public Square conducted by Junior Chamber of Commerce.” [sic] dancing Court Square Home Federal Savings & Loan Marx & Bensdorf Brass Rail Restaurant
01:04:12 - “‘Miss City Beautiful’ appears before many service luncheon clubs, and urges their cooperation in campaign.” Exchange Club Co-operative Club Lion’s Club Jr. Chamber of Commerce
01:06:04 - “‘Miss City Beautiful’ takes part in radio and television programs.”

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1860 - Bygone Days
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Memphis Chamber of Commerce; 1860s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Article from the Bygone Days section of the Commercial Appeal in 1985.

"125 YEARS AGO - April 20, 1860 -- Chamber of Commerce. The board of commerce of this association have contracted for the fine room on the north side of Court Square, on the second story of a new building going up there. The location is an excellent one. The room will be ready on the 1st of August, when the Chamber will go into actual operation. The committee on arbitration and appeals is, however, now ready for business, whenever any case may be referred to them. The prospects of the Chamber are most encouraging."
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Gift of Eric Elam (Director of Operations, Greater Memphis Chamber)
Elam, E.; Frierson, S.;
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Memphis Public Library & Information Center, MPLIC

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1960 - Bygone Days
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Memphis Chamber of Commerce; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Article from the Bygone Days section of the Commercial Appeal in 1985.

"25 YEARS AGO - June 15, 1960 -- A. J. Davies handed over the presidency of the Memphis Chamber of Commerce yesterday to Edward B. LeMaster, urging all Memphians to 'take on a little more braggadocio and tell the world about your fine city.' The new president is head of the realty firm of Edward LeMaster Co. Inc. Le Master will be at the helm of one of the fifty largest Chambers of Commerce in the United States. The Memphis chamber now has a membership of 2,300, largest in its 100-year history. One of the greatest challenges facing Memphis, Davies said, is the establishment of industries here to use the raw products of the Mid-South. LeMaster has been associated with chamber work for two decades. He was a director in 1947-48, vice president in 1953-54 and has had several committee assignments."
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Gift of Eric Elam (Director of Operations, Greater Memphis Chamber)
Elam, E.; Frierson, S.;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1861 - Bygone Days
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Memphis Chamber of Commerce; 1860s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Article from the Bygone Days section of the Commercial Appeal in 1986.

"125 YEARS AGO - Aug. 31, 1861 -- Chamber of Commerce - This institution is flourishing; 31 members have lately been added to it. We are glad to see our merchants and businessmen so alive to the utility of the association. The secretary, Mr. Toof, is an excellent officer, and his efforts have contributed greatly to the chamber's success."
